description: Health begins where we live, work and play. Students are immersed in public, private, and
community-based organizations in Northfield (rural) and Minneapolis-St. Paul (urban) to gain an
understanding of the social determinants of health (environmental conditions, resources and
supports) and the relationship to individual health outcomes through service learning. A special
emphasis is placed on the impact of socioeconomic status, geographic location, and disability on
health disparities. Prerequisites: one course in sociology/anthropology, women's and gender
studies, social work, family studies, economics, political science, environmental studies, or
fullname: Health and Social Inequality: Rural and Urban Perspectives(off campus)
